author: Lisa O'Carroll
title: London council sets up as private landlord
text:
A London council has come up with a radical solution to the capital’s housing shortage bypurchasing a block of flats which it will rent out to private tenants at below market rate.
Related: Through the roof: how London rents are rising – interactive
In what is believed to be the first initiative of its type in the country, the east London council of Barking and Dagenham has bought 100% of a private development from construction company Bouygues and will release 144 new homes on to the market for private renters in October.
It is an innovative way of trying to do something for Generation Rent
Barking and Dagenham council
The development also includes social housing but as part of a regeneration scheme, local councillors decided it should also try to tackle the wider housing shortage which has been identified by both Tories and Labour leaders as the worst in 30 years.
Anyone who earns less than £66,000 per year is eligible for a one or two bedroom property while the cap for a three- or four-bedroom property has been set at £80,000.
“It is an innovative way of trying to do something for Generation Rent,” a spokesman for the council said.
He denied it was social engineering or a bid to attract more middle class tenants to the borough which has traditionally been dominated by council tenants.
“It is about aspirational workers, it is certainly not gentrification. It’s about young professionals who need a decent home but can’t afford the market rents which have rocketed in London,” the spokesman added.
Facebook Twitter Pinterest An interior of a flat in Mill Point, where the rent is £940 a month. Photograph: Barking and Dagenham Reside
Already 1,000 members of the public have registered interest in the 144 homes, said Hakeem Osinaike, divisional director of housing management at the council.
Barking and Dagenham council leaders are hoping other councils will follow suit.
In the past councils have tried to surmount the housing shortage by paying private landlords to take council tenants, but this is the first time a council has effectively become a private landlord itself.
The acquisition of the Abbey Road apartment block cost the council £45m which was funded through a £130m credit facility it secured from the European Investment Bank at below-market interest rates.
It has also set up an independent company, Barking and Dagenham Reside , which will market and manage the block on the council’s behalf.
It’s a win-win for our council, taxpayers, residents and Generation Rent
Saima Ashraf, councillor
The homes are being let out at 80% of market rent, but will still produce a surplus for the council. Two bedroom flats will be available for £940, almost half of what it would cost in neighbouring boroughs such as Hackney where the median rent for a two-bedder is £1,700 .
Jeremy Grind, divisional director of regeneration for Barking and Dagenham council,told the Guardian:
“This isn’t just about housing key workers such as teachers and nurses, it’s about housing the baristas, waiters and waitresses – people who can’t afford to get on the the housing ladder or get access to a council home,” he said.
The scheme will produce a profit for the council which will be ploughed back into more housing.
Councillor Saima Ashraf said: “It’s a win-win for our council, taxpayers, residents and Generation Rent.”
The council aims to get 1,000 flats in its private rental scheme over the the next three years.
“We came up with the idea for Barking and Dagenham Reside because we needed to think of a creative way to build new housing in the middle of an economic downturn,” councillor Cameron Geddes said.
Andrew Boff, the Conservative housing spokesman on the Greater London Assembly, told the Guardian he thought the scheme was one of the most innovative in the country, from a council financing and housing point of view.
He described the council’s development as “fantastic” and said it could be part of a solution to the drastic housing shortage in Britain.
